text: When I enter a negotiation, I notice the emotional state of the other party and adjust my approach accordingly.
I recognize the difference between what people say and what they truly mean, and I read the signals beneath the surface.
When I feel pressure or tension rising, I pause and slow my pace before responding.
I let emotions guide my decisions during negotiations, and I react impulsively without thinking through the consequences.
When I prepare for a negotiation, I map out different scenarios and plan responses for each one.
I recognize what the other party values most, and I shape my offers to align with their interests.
When I notice hidden motives or fears, I use them as information to guide my strategy rather than react to them.
I enter negotiations without clear goals or limits, and I let the other side push me into decisions I later regret.
When I use silence intentionally, I create space for the other party to reveal information or reconsider their position.
I recognize when attacks or pressure are tactics, and I don't take them personally.
When I understand power dynamics and leverage points, I position myself more strategically.
I let assumptions guide my negotiation instead of gathering facts, and I negotiate with guesses rather than data.
When I control my tone, breathing, and pace even under pressure, I maintain psychological advantage.
I recognize when I need to step back and observe the full picture before making a move.
When I anticipate objections before they appear, I prepare layered responses that weaken resistance quietly.
I let the moment choose me instead of choosing my moments, and I react from ego rather than strategy.
When I identify what the other party fears, wants, and may hide, I gain clearer insight into their position.
I recognize the value of patience and understand that silence can be more powerful than arguments.
When I create hooks that make saying yes easier for the other party, negotiations become more cooperative.
I negotiate without understanding the other side's incentives or history, and I enter conversations blind.
